text.name: sys_description
text.text: The Amiga 500 (A500) is the first entry-level model in Commodore's Amiga family of computers. Released in 1987, it competed against the Atari 520 ST. The Amiga 500 uses a Motorola 68000 microprocessor clocked at 7MHz, with 512KB of RAM, the "Denise" GPU and the "Paula" sound card for four-channel PCM audio output. It could switch between resolutions starting at 320x256 in 32 colors up to 640x512 in 16 colors. Later models would offer up to 128 colors. Cult games such as Shadow of the Beast originated on the Amiga 500.
